text.#text: The

A
			 high-quality, highly competitive education for all students is imperative for
			 the economic growth and productivity of the United States, for its effective
			 national defense, and for achievement of the historical aspiration to be one
			 Nation of equal citizens. It is therefore necessary and proper to overcome the
			 nationwide phenomenon of educationally inadequate or inequitable State public
			 school systems, in which high-quality public schools serve high-income
			 communities and poor-quality schools serve low-income, urban, rural, and
			 minority communities.

There exists in
			 the States an ever-widening educational opportunity gap for low-income, urban,
			 rural, and minority students characterized by the following:

Highly
			 differential educational expenditures among local educational agencies within
			 States.

Continuing
			 disparities within the States in students’ access to the opportunity to learn
			 indicators described in

Radically
			 differential educational achievement among local educational agencies within
			 the States, as measured by the following:

Achievement in
			 mathematics, reading or language arts, and science on State academic
			 achievement tests and measures, including the academic assessments described in

Advanced
			 placement courses offered and taken.

Scholastic
			 Aptitude Test (SAT) and ACT Assessment scores.

Dropout rates and
			 graduation rates.

College-going and
			 college-completion rates.

Job
			 placement and retention rates and indices of job quality.

As a consequence
			 of this educational opportunity gap, the quality of a child’s education depends
			 largely upon where the child’s family lives, and the detriments of lower
			 quality public education are imposed particularly on—

children from
			 low-income families;

children living in
			 urban and rural areas; and

minority
			 children.

Since 1965, the
			 Congress, in exercising its spending authority, has provided substantial
			 Federal financial assistance to the States for the improvement of their public
			 school systems. In their expenditure and oversight of this assistance, the
			 States have failed systematically to achieve the purpose of the Congress in
			 providing the assistance, namely the effective education of all the children of
			 the United States.

To ensure that all
			 students in public elementary schools and secondary schools receive educational
			 opportunities that enable the students—

to acquire the
			 knowledge and skills necessary for responsible citizenship, including the
			 ability to participate fully in the political process through informed
			 electoral choice;

to meet
			 challenging State student academic achievement standards; and

to be able to
			 compete and succeed in a global economy.

To end the

			 school systems.
